author: Edwmg21
title: Highbury hospital again
body:
My son who was on one of the wards and then was moved after he was assaulted by another patient x2  
He has greatly improved over the last 12 weeks he has been in hospital. Unfortunately on Sunday night he was assaulted again head butted on his mouth!!  
We again were not informed of the incident by any one on duty at the time of the incident.  
We actually learned about the incident from a social worker on Wednesday who rang his mother to talk about a care package so he can be discharged.. unfortunately SS cannot as yet can not offer a package due to shortage of care workers ect ect ect ??? We are more than willing to help with the support package but he is ill and needs professional mental health and social care support too.  
Surely his safety is of paramount priority!  
So how comes he’s suffered 3 assaults over a period of 12 weeks.  
It’s not acceptable that he has been in a safe place ??? and yet still been injured.  
These patients are vulnerable and need observing. They all have various problems and are or can be volatile! Surely that’s what the staff are paid to do!!! Look out for any kind of tension on the wards and between the patients 🤔🤔😡

author: Neel
title: Gradual decline of the pharmacy service
body: I came to the pharmacy to collect my methotrexate prescription last week. Once again it was not ready as the pharmacy had not checked when it was next due. In the last 12 months I have noticed a gradual decline of the service here. I used to have no problems and had excellent service before. It seems there are new staff/management. If I could choose a different pharmacy I would but unfortunately stuck as my rheumatology consultant here is really good.

readBy.name: London North West University Healthcare NHS Trust

author: Medievalman
title: A fascinating procedure
body:
Such a positive experience. A procedure I was dreading turned out to be fascinating! From written information to reassuring and friendly staff, it couldn't have been better.  
One thing that might be added to at least one of the information leaflets is the internet link for feedback. This information was available at the Endoscopy Unit but my mind was on other things and it took a few on-line searches to decide the best link to use.

readBy.name: York and Scarborough Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: keycovid19
title: COVID-19 questions
body:
I received an appointment letter from the audiology dept at PRI.  
Ridiculous me just not able to see these 7 Covid questions and answer "no" to all questions.  
Total waste of time.

author: plutodn39
title: I need to speak to the practice
body: I have been ringing since 8 am in the morning, 43 calls and I still cannot get through to talk to the receptionist let alone the doctor. I have been on medication for a bad back but the medication is no longer working and I am in pain and need to speak to the practice.

author: Oscar03
title: Covid testing before surgery
body: I can’t thank the super helpful staff on duty enough. After a tough consultant appointment which resulted in being scheduled for emergency surgery in Glasgow I was asked to go for a Covid test to ensure surgery would be undertaken. Jenna and her senior Doreen tried all they could to ensure this happened even going up to the ward to try and find the consultant to put a referral through to them! They went well over and above and provided a very through and reassuring service - a big thank you to them both.

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

author: Chota
title: Zoledronic acid infusion
body: I wasn't given any information about the procedure however, I wasn't in the least bit concerned as I know other people who have had a similar infusion for their osteoporosis with no associated problems at all. I was asked if I was allergic to anything twice by the nurse. I said as far as I was aware, I wasn't. Twelve hours after the infusion, in the middle of the night, I was woken by the pain in my joints all over my body and was unable to move. I tried to stand up which was impossible but I did eventually manage to move. The next day, I felt really ill, unable to eat but did keep drinking. I had an upset stomach and felt cold even though it was 30c that day. I rang my GP who wasn't concerned, told me to take paracetamol and that I'd be fine in a couple of days, which was encouraging as I was going on holiday the following day. I did feel much better, not 100% by any means. One week later, I had another incident of pain in all my joints but it was particularly bad in my neck. Again, it cleared up after a couple of days and then a week later, whilst still away, I woke to discover problems with my sight and since then, haven't been able to drive. On returning home, I visited my optician who assured me my eyes were fine however, I still have blurred vision and am still unable to drive.

author: braceqw87
title: Unhappy with sharing bathroom
body:
I am currently receiving chemo treatment so when I arrived at A&E the nursing staff gave me a private room straight away as my immune system weak. I did have to move out of that room for a Covid-19 positive patient but the nurses ensured that my curtains in the bay were pulled to protect me. I was in A&E for about 12 hours as I had to wait to get a bed in the ward. The staff in A&E were lovely and looked after me well. I did have a long wait for a bed in the ward but that was out of the nurses control.  
The staff in 1 East are cheerful and have created a calming atmosphere within the ward. All staff from domestics, catering, porters, HCA, Nurses, Physio, Doctors are amazing and take the time to get to know me as a person and not just my wants or needs. The doctors and nurses are good at clarifying my treatment and very accommodating to my needs. I am fortunate to have my own room within the ward but my bathroom is interlinked with another bedroom and I think that sharing a bathroom in the 21st century is inappropriate especially a female sharing with a male but this is out of the nurse’s control. I feel that this objectifies my dignity.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: tigercd87
title: Maternity experience
body:
My antenatal and maternity care under the QEUH remains one of the most terrifying, dehumanising experiences of my life. I had always planned to have more than one child, but that's not an option any more.  
It's difficult to describe the issues because they are obviously so widespread. I felt that midwives had no interest in listening to my concerns, requests for support being repeatedly ignored or laughed at, left alone on a recovery ward for hours with no water, separated from my daughter and no one able to give me any information and getting angry because I was upset about it. The only thing anyone did have time for was to talk at me about contraception in a really aggressive manner despite me repeatedly saying no thanks.  
A year later I still wake up in a sweat, petrified someone has taken away my daughter and won't tell me why. I didn't see her for 10 hours after she was born and kept getting told she would be brought to me any minute. The poor maternity care we received has had such a profound impact and I'm tortured by it all the more because I wasn't in a position to make a complaint within the timeframe. I feel responsible for other woman who suffer under this broken maternity care system.

author: guidebb55
title: I was admitted with Covid 19
body:
I was admitted to A&E. An assessor called to my home first before requesting an ambulance. The assessor cared for me until the ambulance arrived. I had called 999 earlier in the week but the assessor said I did not need to be admitted even though I felt I should have been. I was unable to leave my bed due to low oxygen levels so my daughter called ambulance on Saturday. The non-emergency ambulance was in another area so I had to wait 90 minutes before it arrived. Once I arrived in A&E I was seen within 30 minutes and given my own room. A&E was very busy and I was ignored and I had to keep making requests such as a blanket or a cup of tea/water.  
I was admitted to 2 south and really impressed with how caring and gentle the staff are. The staff keep me informed on my treatment and even wrote my medication on a piece of paper so I can tell my daughter who is a nurse at another hospital. I am 100% happy with the care provided and the food is great quality, it just like being in a hotel.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Yazmd45
title: My mum's fall
body:
My mum had a very bad fall and fractured her shoulder , she was initially seen at Sandwell hospital at the beginning of August 21. She was sent home with a sling and advised that she would be recalled to the clinic with four weeks for a further xray.  
Six weeks on we had not received any appointment, I rang the Trauma and Orthopaedic clinic several times, spoke to different administration staff only to be told that no further appointment had been booked in and this would be flagged up with higher management, I was assured that some-one would get back to. Needless to say that this never happened.  
As I had not received any call back a week later, I rang the clinic again, this time I was lucky enough to get through to a very helpful member of staff on reception. They checked my Mum's information, noted that she needed to be seen and manged to fit Mum in for an appointment at the fracture clinic the very next day.  
My Mum has now been seen, she has had another x-ray and has been referred for physio-therapy, and is well on the way to recovery. All staff at the fracture clinic were brilliant, very caring and professional, A very big thank you to all, but especially to the receptionist who didn't just take a message to pass onto somebody else, but took immediate action. THANK YOU.

readBy.name: Sandwell and West Birmingham Hospitals NHS Trust

title: Fast and effective
body:
Invited for vaccination at 1030am. Jabbed by 2.30pm. This really is superb service.
Practice is clean and the team are kind and empathetic. 
 Thank You!



.

title: Poor Service
body: The Service being received at this Surgery is Poor.  I would not recommend joining this Surgery. The Reception assess medical issues and based on their triage book appointments. The first routine appointments are 20+ days ahead.

title: Flu jab
body: The whole process was extremely well organised from start to finish and I was through very quickly and easily

author: Emmy
title: Excellent GP consultation
body: I had called about a medical issue which was possibly worsened by worry with respect to a similar issue in the past. The GP did a wonderful job of explaining what was and was not concerning, validated my worries, checked back I understood, and highlighted other areas of care which should be addressed. His reassurance and kind consultation really helped.

readBy.name: East Renfrewshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: BellaM
title: Looked after with care and tenderness
body: My mother was discharged yesterday after almost 6 weeks in Ward 8 at RAH. Mum is nearly 95 and was quite confused about the whole thing, but staff handled this with such patience, and looked after her with care and tenderness. Thank you to them all.

author: Happy patient surgical ward 2
title: In good hands
body: Tumour removed. Feeling comfortable, safe and in good hands.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: AG39
title: Clearly cares about women
body: 4th baby but ended up being my first breastfeeding journey all because of a midwife that took time. I believe this woman was passionate about breastfeeding, and clearly cares about women too. She no doubt stayed longer at the visits than need and called when she wasn’t supposed to with things to help with the feeding. She had the nicest nature ever and she is definitely an asset to the southern trust. I wish all new mums could be appointed this woman. I hope she knows how grateful I am.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Scotlandmole
title: Confusing information
body: I had a mole removed from my back over 6 weeks ago at the skin cancer clinic. I was told by the consultant the results would take 2-3 weeks. After 3 weeks I phoned dermatology for the results, the reply was as I was seen by a service that was out sourced at the weekend, it would take 6 - 8 weeks. I questioned if those who are seen by NHS so not out sourced would wait as long for results and told they are all busy but NHS patients tend to get results quicker. Communication is very confusing and after waiting nearly 7 weeks I still have not received the results, this is very anxiety provoking and I would recommend that all staff give a realistic and consistent  timeframe and patients should not be concerned about if a service is out sourced. If it had been explained by the consultant it was very busy and wait time was 6-8 weeks this would be so helpful and reduce anxiety.

readBy.name: MASScot- Melanoma Action and Support Scotland

author: pepsicola04
title: Delays for prescription
body: I was appointed to Dermatology in mid September. I have been waiting for my prescription to be sent from UHM since. (2+ weeks). I have called dermatology 3 times to chase up the prescription. I called back today and spoke with a very nice, kind secretary who advised me there is a back log in typing. They will kindly process my letter today, however this may not happen if tasked with other work. I find it appalling that there can be a delay like this for a prescription for medications to treat cancerous/pre cancerous lesions. To allow four weeks or more I feel is unacceptable. I appreciate the appalling stress ALL NHS staff are under given the circumstances, however patients cannot be left without their prescription for this length of time. Surely funding must be reviewed for extra support for the admin teams in addition to clinical? To think that departments were stood down in the initial phase of the pandemic and have had to play catch up with no additional support is fool hardy. More thought is required to ensure more efficient systems are in place. It is admin that is letting the NHS down.

author: JMcC21
title: My son's orthopedic surgery
body:
My son who is 14 fractured his wrist. We attended RAH A&E, brilliant experience. Every member of staff was kind and explained exactly what was happening. Once assessed at A&E he was reviewed by an orthopedic consultant and we were given the opinions with regard treatment. The nurses and doctors were amazing. They made sure he wasn't in pain, they made him feel comfortable. We left that day with a clear plan.  
He was then reviewed on 2 occasions at the fracture clinic. Unfortunately the position changed and he had to be referred to RHSC. The consultant arranged this and provided us with a letter to go to RHSC. Again, this was an excellent experience. My son was assessed by an ortho consultant and they advised he required an operation the next morning. Everyone treated him with kindness and respect, they explained everything to him gaining his informed consent and also reassuring myself.  
He attended for the operation which went really well. The anesthetist was amazing, explained everything to him, reassured him and he went into the operation feeling calm. Surgeon was brilliant. Nurses were brilliant.I feel that every member of the NHS staff was amazing through my son's journey.  
When on the ward a play assistant came to see him and brought him a PS4 to play with. He was delighted and it helped to pass the time.

title: Great Practice
body: I have accompanied 98 yrs old recently widowed man with a hearing problem for cataract surgery. The staff was absolutely brilliant -courteous,  professional, and with a sense of humor to put him at ease. The clinic is kept clean. The surgery went well, leaving the patient very happy with the results and will to live a bit longer. Thank you Spa Medica  staff for all your hard work x

author: Loubelle41
title: Lack of communication in childrens services
body:
What is wrong with children's services, let me tell you the number one cause of all the problems we've faced... communication!  
About a week of preparation goes into these appointments on my behalf, the planning of treats, the numbing cream, the horrific fear of needles she has developed talked through, drove all the way to the city hospital yesterday to show her where we were going to help her anxiety.  
Blood test for my daughter at at 2.40pm today at the children's centre who were, I was told, brilliant with anxiety and autism, would be totally understanding, definitely the right place to go.  
I rang at 2.40pm to say we were going to be late as I was struggling to get her out the door, told don't worry just get here as soon as you can, I will make sure they know you are still coming.  
Arrived at 3.05 went into reception told we needed to go a different way, 3.20 I managed to coax my daughter around to the other side of the building to be told we had been put down as "did not attend" and referred back to the doctor.  
They had no prior notice of her diagnosis, anxiety or that we were late, no messages got through. Despite the fact that when the appointment was booked I explained how severe my daughter's anxiety was and I rang to ask if we could pop down for a visit prior to the appointment, explaining, yet again how anxious my little girl was.  
Both of us drove home in tears.  
So sick of this system and its false promises, can people pass messages on when they say they are going to, I can't take anymore false hope.  
I broke down at the door, said you have no idea what I have been through in the last 7 hours to get her here for now, yes we were late and I totally understand that's not helpful but I am doing everything I can and nothing is helping, nothing is working, nothing is changing.  
Oh and we have been discharged from family services because apparently Mum has it all in hand do you know what - Mum is bloody sick of having it all in her hands and is desperate for help.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

title: Great service
body:
I was called in for vascular ablation procedure,
after only waiting 12 weeks from initial consultation. The Consultant was brilliant along with the superb nursing team. Everyone put me at my ease as i was very anxious.
Can’t praise the hospital enough.  Well done.  Thanks .

title: Efficient and very helpful
body: I found everyone very efficient, helpful and reassuring. The doctor who saw me took the time to ensure  she answered all my questions very clearly. Can’t recommend them enough.

title: Blood test
body: Blood test done. Completely painless, cannot praise enough. Thought  I saw a doctor in the distance turned out to be a yeti ridding a unicorn.

title: Flu vaccination.
body:
A really impressive and efficient performance this year. No queue, perfect timed walk through, happy smiling good humoured Clinicians.
Way to go Fordingbridge GP!

title: Swift and thorough response to my cancer concerns
body:
I became concerned about a skin lesion during the height of the pandemic. I am aware but not obsessed with my skin as I suffer from vitiligo. 
I completed the online consultation which worked brilliantly. I was able to share pictures of my lesion of concern. I was called to the practice to be seen face to face by a very nice female doctor who took high resolution photographs and who referred me under the two week cancer protocol. As I left her consultation she offered an alternative possible diagnosis which I found very  reassuring as I was extremely concerned.
I had a call from Scarborough Hospital waiting list service and was seen at Malton Hospital by a Specialist from South Tees Hospital within 2 weeks. Their specialist assessment equipment enabled them to diagnose my lesion in the consultation as being a collection of blood cells and not a melanoma as I had feared. This was treated by the Consultant as evidence indicated it was effective. Interestingly every patient he and the Nurse Specialist had seen that day had presented with my particular diagnosis and not something more sinister 
This was brilliant, compassionate and evidence based care in the height of a Pandemic. The online consultation I found to be really helpful as it gave me time to express myself and concerns and to attach photographs.
Thank you to the Doctor I saw and to the Receptionists who were very compassionate on the telephone and very efficient.

title: Appreciated Service
body: Evening receptionist was very helpful on this occasion in arranging an appointment for my parent who had been trying for sometime.  Thank you, your understanding was very much appreciated.

author: ECDC
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: A wonderful experience
body:
I had a wonderful experience with the ECDC service. The staff were very pleasant and helpful. Nothing was a hassle to them. I went for a CT scan which went very well and I had my bloods taken. The service didn't take any time at all and I was amazed at how fast I had a scan and got the results. I was very relieved to be given good news. I felt I was very well informed throughout the process too. Whenever I attend services within the NHS I feel I am always well attended and well treated. I was shown kindness and compassion throughout the process. The staff are very dedicated too.  
We are very lucky to have our NHS and it should be cherished.

title: disappointing ineffectual treatment
body:
I have many issues with the treatment received at health share. I will start with the only positive which is that (most) of the individuals I have met in person where kind and knowledgeable but just seem to be stuck in a poor system. 

Other than that I’m afraid I have been very disappointed with healthshare. Some of my issues are listed below: 
-appointments cancelled regularly 
-I’ve never spoken to the same person more than once, each time I am given completely different advice 
-I have seen no improvements in my pain over 6 months and no one seems to be able to offer anything new other than more of the same
-telephone appointment assessments were completely ineffectual, I don’t know how Physical pain can be assessed in such a way.
- dismissive responses to how much I’m struggling with the pain 
-when I tried to express some of these issues to someone over the phone, I was treated very poorly to the point that I was brought to tears. They expressed no compassion and threatened to with  hold treatment if I did not ‘pull myself together’ and ‘calm down’.

title: Awful! no empathy.lies!
body:
I have to call 10 times a day for any simple thing!
office staff are incredibly rude and impolite! can t get anything done. You have to chase up EVERYTHING!
the veg market is more organised, professional and respectful than the staff in this Clinique!
unbelievable!

title: Really Tried to help me, it was appreciated
body:
I have difficulty getting some medications due to a falling out with my previous GP.
However since joining CRS they do whatever they can, and judge me on their experiences with me, not what others have said. Even this small thing was enough to make my day. Thank you to the staff at CRS, you are lovely people!

author: Jenny123
title: We were seen and discharged quickly
body:
My daughter had fallen at nursery and banged her head, she seemed fine that day, however over night she began vomiting. The next morning she was still vomiting so we decided to take her to the kids A and E to get her checked.  
We were met at the front entrance by a very friendly nurse who asked a few questions and sent us through to book in. The receptionist who took my daughters details was polite and friendly.  
After a short wait Shauna the nurse who would be looking after us showed us through to a space in the A and E department. Shauna was very friendly and professional and went out of her way to put my very worried 4 yr old at ease. She took time to explain everything to her.  
We were quickly seen by a junior doctor and then a consultant. Both of whom took time to go through what had happened and my daughters symptoms. They thoroughly examined her (despite her best protests with saying “NO!” to everything they were asking her to do). We were discharged home with advice on worsening which made me feel very reassured.  
We were lucky that even given the current demand in A and E departments we were seen and discharged quickly. I just want to say a huge thank you to Shauna, the other nurses and the doctors for being so caring and continuing to do it all with a smile on their faces despite the busy and stressful times they are working in at present.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

title: Fantastic staff
body: Once again, fantastic support and treatment from the wonderful Kington surgery staff. From booking my appointment to being seen, I felt my well being was priority. Thank you

author: pelicanjm34
title: All very easy
body: All very easy . Minimum wait. Staff excellent

author: filingrj74
title: Flu vaccination
body: Got jab after queuing for about 15 minutes

author: hydrarn64
title: Dealt with faultlessly
body: Took me less than 3 minutes from entering the front door to leaving by the back. Dealt with faultlessly. I was imagining having to hang about for 20 minutes or so but it was run like clockwork. Congratulations to nurses and administrators for the efficiency of effort

author: shuddergh86
title: All very organised
body:
Welcoming and friendly staff. All very organised an I was in and out in minutes.
This has been my experience every flu vaccine season. It is an excellent Practice with fantastic staff. Congratulations and thanks to each one.

author: Dynamodebs 56
title: Walk in flu jab
body: Was asked various questions on arrival, had my temperature taken, then waited less than 5 minutes to be seen.

author: carinafp66
title: It went smoothly
body: I had my flu jab today at the Nightingale Practice, it went smoothly. I feel alright at the moment.

title: Great practice
body: Very helpful excellent reception on arrive overall very happy with my outcome all staff are very helpful

title: The best of care
body:
I was referred to a consultant thoracic surgeon from Glenfield for lung surgery. 
From my initial consultation I immediately felt at ease and had complete confidence that I  would be well looked after.
I was given a date for surgery on that first meeting and within a few days I received a call from the lung nurse specialists to check if I had any questions or concerns and to inform me that I would be looked after by the team on ward 26. I was assured that they were a brilliant team and that it was a lovely ward.
I have to say from the minute I walked into the ward I could not have asked for better treatment.
Everyone, the nurses, the hca's, the porters and cleaners and the physiotherapists were marvellous. So caring and professional they made my stay in hospital a good experience in a time when relatives cannot be with you and you feel alone.
I have made a good recovery and I wish to thank you all.

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Leicester NHS Trust

title: Going the extra mile
body: I have been visiting this practice for a number of years and continue to be wowed by the caring and conscientious nurses and doctors there. Always smiling, reassuring, efficient and available - thank you Grafton Medical.

author: severitycf63
title: Thanks to everyone
body:
I was in so much pain.  
Thank you to the Doctors, sister, and all the nurses day-shift and night-shift. Also the physiotherapy girls. Also the coffee was most welcome. The meals were super. The nurses made sure the meals were well organised. I cannot thank everyone enough. From opening my eyes in the morning, nothing was too much trouble till I fell asleep at nite I was helped in every way. I did not no I was so ill but thanks to every-one I made a full recovery. I will never forget how busy the nurses are but always have time to help.

author: gammasg97
title: Vaccine programme
body: I have just had a booster vaccibe after the first 2 doses, all went well. Although the clinic was busy today everything was very well organised and all the staff were very helpful and polite.

title: Excellent experience
body: I joined Lionwood Medical Practice a couple of weeks ago and every contact I have had so far has been excellent. I have met several reception staff and they have all been helpful, professional and kind. The HCP who did our new patient check was great too. Couldn't be more impressed

author: Nunya Biniss
title: So kind and knowledgeable
body: I love the NHS. Carol was so kind and knowledgeable about everything we talked about, and she put my mind at ease when they tried to take bloods, You should give her a raise!

title: Good organisation
body: Attended flu clinic walk through, was very well organised and everyone very helpful. Very reassuring with everything that’s going on

title: Friendly staff and good treatment/care
body: I visited the catheter care unit for an angiogram. Friendly caring staff . Only one negative egg sandwiches but they were my choice so I can't really complain.

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Derby and Burton NHS Foundation Trust

title: Great Patient Care
body: I am moving from this practice reluctantly and only due to a house move.  Doctors have never let me down and their care is exceptional, I cannot fault them. My only criticism is what appears to be a frequent turnover of reception staff and some can be very abrupt and cold at times, apart from that the Doctors are amazing. Totally recommend this practice. Thankyou for the care you have given me over the past 11 years

title: The staff make the hospital
body:
Having been rushed it, blue lights flashing, I was in the stroke ward for ten days and the care was amazing. I was classified as 'independent', so really only needed monitoring.
All of the staff were attentive, friendly and caring. 
I had every test under the sun and  only discharged when they and I were happy.
Hospital food? Yes bland, but the salads were first rate.
Yes, there were the occasional  moments of madness, when emergencies happened, but you do have to just have to go with it.

readBy.name: Surrey and Sussex Healthcare NHS Trust

title: Fantastic
body: My mum was palliative care the dignity and compassion the ambulance service provided to my mum was amazing I will never forget them xxx

title: Fantastic
body: My mum was taken to the queen Elizabeth hospital in woolwich the ambulance crew were amazing they treated her with dignity knowing she was palliative care I will never forget them or their faces I would give them the biggest cuddle if I could they even made sure I was ok the beating heart of the NHS Thankyou so much xxxc

author: gizmo69
title: Lack of duty of Care
body:
Hi im writing this today as im at my wits end last September I was heading to tescos to grab some shopping and upon trying to walk home I had a sudden pain across the whole of my back and I collapsed I was unconscious for 15 or so mins b4 I came round and managed to pull myself up and drag myself home. 2 days after, I was admitted to york hospital where I explained the problem. They looked at my heart as they thought I'd had a possible stroke. I was treated with statins due to irregularities.  
Speed forward to march, when I collapsed again to be taken to york and again they looked at my heart. Xrays and finally a ct scan was requested where upon further investigation it turned out I had a fractured t12 in my spine. I was told that I needed to follow up with my gp.  
Speed 4 ward again to may/june and still no help from gp I was rushed to york again due to no feelings in my left leg and toilet probs where again I had another ctscan to find l2/l3/l4/l5/l6 had collapsed and t12 fractured. The hospital and was told I have problems where my spine is like I am 85, and its a prob with the bones basically.  
After a while, the nurse was very rude in the fact I wanted help was rushed in a ambulance, yet they threw me out the hospital without a way to get home and said it was not there responsibility so I was stranded and had to beg a stranger to pay for a cab to get home. I didnt ask to go hospital, I was ordered to go being unemployed I was given a walker and told I had to leave the hospital.  
I was advised to talk to my gp about the problem, upon trying unsuccessfully to get a face 2 face with gp in july, I still needed help but was refused help. The gp said they were not responsible for getting in contact with physio, I would need to do that myself, which I thought eh not right. I also asked about what was happening regarding my diagnosis yet my doctor refused to diagnose the obvious problem.  
I have been trying to apply to pip for over 1 year and due to no communications between hospital and gp I am in limbo. I find this absolutely crazy that there has been no diagnosis but told its a degenerative bone disorder at the hospital, so I am at a loss. I cannot walk too far and the speed its accelerating. I am now in even more pain as I feel my shoulders and neck are now showing signs of more damage due to trying 2 even do anything :(  
Physio were useless the gp was useless, and I feel ive been mistreated. ontop of the back problem, I suffer from bi-polar and the fact im in constant pain. My anxiety and depression is through the roof .. I am very worried I daren't not go out due to collapsing. I have troubles at home with basic chores, but im being ignored. no occupational therapy nothing so im left feeling suicidal and hopeless and scared :(  
I have to goto york again on the 14/10 for a stress test and im panicking I cant cope and i feel totally lost my mental health advocate is doing all he can but even that isnt helping as the last year pip want the diagnosis they want the reports but there not willing to see me so im writing this here as a last attempt to try to get answers and the help i need ...  
Im sorry but i really cannot take this much longer

readBy.name: York and Scarborough Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Open times
body: Haven't been today but since when has the surgery been closed thursday afternoons, I'm sure iv been in contact with them on a thursday afternoon. Only find out today that its closed with trying to phone an speak to someone over my medication

title: Too many bad experiences
body: I've had a few bad experiences with kingsreet over the years but after being referred by GP for a procedure which could have caused permanent damage or an unwanted pregnancy I am quite upset and have lost trust. I only found out it was unsuitable with my condition that the GP was fully aware of after sharing the information on a whim with the clinic I was referred on the the day of the procedure. A complete waste of mine and the medical staff at the clinics time, not to mention the implications if I failed to tell them and they went ahead. Tried calling the surgery to get an appointment to discuss and "there's nothing available" more of my time to waste calling every morning whilst Im working. They put my health at risk and I can't even be referred for a telephone consultation to discuss without waiting even longer...

title: Once again good service
body: I have submitted a review previously but felt I had to do so again on behalf of my husband.  My husband had a health issue today he was concerned about and filled in the online form.  Within 30 minutes GP had called him offering him a face to face 45 minutes later.  The receptionists have been incredibly helpful particularly lately with regard to both my husband’s and daughter’s health issues. I cannot thank them enough.

title: Brilliant staff in the Acute Medical Unit
body:
I was taken by ambulance and immediately seen at A&E. After processesing I was moved to Acute Medical Unit (AMU), bay 9.

From the offset the nurses and care assistants were excellent. They were methodological and friendly at the same time.

Know matter how busy they got they were always on top of things.

I would also like to thank a young lady cleaner who again was methodological in her processes, which helped with my anxiety.

Thanks to the porters and all other support staff.

You all helped me though the unfortunate illness that I was diagnosed with.

Thanks!

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Leicester NHS Trust

author: ECDC
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Wonderful Early Cancer Diagnostic Centre Service
body:
I have just been through the ECDC pathway and I am very pleased with the care I received from them. The staff were very organised and I couldn't believe how quickly I got a CT scan and then my results. Everything happened within a couple weeks and it all went very smoothly. When the staff said they would contact me about my care, they did exactly that. I was never kept waiting. Katie, the cancer nurse specialist, was very reassuring and was able to answer any questions I had which put me at ease. Radiology were also very pleasant and welcoming. When I received my results from Katie she immediately put me at ease by saying it was good news and there were no signs of cancer before explaining what they did find on my CT scan, which thankfully was something very minor. My GP followed up with me this morning and we both agreed that this is an invaluable service.  
  
Maybe the only thing I could say that would make a small improvement would be when I was waiting in the waiting area for my scan, if someone was able to pop over and just say "hello, nice to meet you. We won't be long in taking you for scan". For me that would've stopped me wondering when it was turn to go in next. However, I am being very picky in saying that. I really can't fault my treatment and I am very pleased with the care I received from everyone.  
  
Well done everyone!

title: Quick response to my health question
body: Rang Cedars Monday 27th and the Dr rang me back that morning , so relieved to have spoken to her, was reassured and put me at ease encouraging me to call back with any deterioration of symptoms. You have been under so much pressure, thank you for being there when i needed you

title: awful service
body: you can never get through to any one and simply asked to leave a message, There are no email address's you can use or any other lines to ring. Looks like you have to actually visit the center to get any where. its really frustrating especially when you need medical help and theirs no way of getting through.

title: Put off
body: When calling the Cubbington practice to be met with a sharp toned abrupt authorative sounding voice is a shame, as this is easily rectified with staff training.

title: Basford Light Treatmant
body: Staff are kind and professional, it is an easy location to get to with parking and flexible appointments to fit around work.

title: Terrible practice
body:
Have just spent over an hour awaitin' (as the tape doesn't appear to have 'g's on the end of words) an answer.  My MS meds are late - need them by Monday!

I seem to have to call every month - not rocket science for Lloyds to program this feature.

I have a number of questions: Are LPCH adequately staffed? Is there a high staff churn rate?  Why does nobody want to stay? Why can't the queue let you know your position in the queue? Is the process or the system capable?  Does it function properly?  Are Lloyds taking the money to supply/deliver and not being honest with the incapacity?

title: Brilliant service
body: Absolutely fantastic experience despite my nervousness I sailed through the cataract procedure purely down to the professionalism and caring of the staff can not recommend enough, fantastic thank you, and my vision is now superb, life changing is all I can say.

title: Brilliant Hospital
body: Just had a total hip replacement and cannot praise the hospital high enough for the planning, organisational once in hospital care and expert surgeon and support staff

title: Good medical staff
body: The surgery are very pro-active in contacting their patients over the pandemic, ensuring they get their prescriptions and organising Vaccination clinics like the Flu one today!

title: Appointments
body: Very disappointed with the service provided by receptionist, they don’t have the clue what’s going on. The only thing they know is call tomorrow.

title: Worst hospital in london
body: Arrived once in ambulance and twice at A&E with chest pains. Had ECG and blood pressure taken and then turfed out even though I had a heart attack a year earlier. Any other hospital would hook you up to a moniter and listen to your concerns. Not this hospital, they want you out so fast they even forget to take the iv out of your arm.

title: Beware of ward 408 Cardiology Ward
body: Admitted as an emergency with heart failure. Staff are supposed to complete a comprehensive care/social care report but did nothing. They are supposed to give details of contact number and instructions on what to do if your conditions or an emergency but once  again did nothing. Make sure you leave with a proper care plan. My condition worsen to the point the consultant now consider it to be 'very severe'. They discharged me knowing I would have to wait 5 hours for transport after they made me Covid contact. Very poor discharge staff/nurses.

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Derby and Burton NHS Foundation Trust

title: Adequate
body: Flu jabs. Well organised with professional and welcoming staff. First time I’ve been inside the surgery for almost 2 yrs. Covid protocols in place.

title: Extremely grateful
body:
After taking the plunge and phoning the practice, I have been really grateful for the help received from my doctor. From the initial phone consultation to the follow up call. Thank you.
 Anxiety and depression are real. Don’t be afraid to talk.

title: Horrible service
body: Utterly disappointed by the service I have received from the GP Surgery. I have been trying to book a telephonic appointment with the doctor for 4 days in a row, to simply order a prescription as I am a new patient and cannot do it online. I needed to get the prescription by 30 September and have failed to do so as the practice cannot accommodate me by phoning me after my working hours, even after I explicitly explained that I cannot receive calls between 7:00 and 15:00 as I am a teacher, but instead phones in those hours and then cannot assist me when I phone back. I will be moving GP Surgeries and will not recommend this practice to any one.

title: Prompt service
body: The receptionist dealt with me quickly as did the pharmacist for my flu vaccine. Pharmacist. Also asked questions about my general heath.

author: venusky86
title: A difficult experience made 10 times worse
body:
We were referred to Centre for Life (CFL) by another consultant within the trust.  
We explained our circumstances at length at the initial appointment only to be told very rudely we wouldn’t be helped. We had further appointments every four months where we met with a number of doctors of varying rude tones, but who all failed to show us any compassion.  
We were referred for some treatment at another service within the trust only to be told we weren’t eligible (surely CFL should establish this). We were then wrongly advised by a locum doctor they felt we were eligible and it would be raised at the MDT meeting. We were never raised because the lead consultant disagreed - but we were not informed of this decision until we chased it.  
We called after having no contact and no scheduled appointments, to ask about testing that should be repeated following NHS guidelines. I called 4 times over 4 weeks. No one ever called me back until I managed to speak with a nurse who said ‘what exactly are your wanting from us’. Perhaps we are wanting basic care and patient dignity? That is too much to ask from CFL.  
We cancelled an appointment arranged after this call due to the tone of the nurse and general distressing attitude of the CFL. There has been no calls or follow up contact now for over a year. I don’t even know if we have been discharged from their service.  
They have made an already difficult experience 10 times worse than it needs to be due to their lack of care and compassion. It felt like they only care about results and their statistics.

readBy.name: The Newcastle upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: Heh
title: Appointment pre warning
body:
At first felt very overwhelmed as it was my first experience and was made to feel at ease after a few minutes and staff more than happy to help with any questions  
Just a pre warning before appointment of what would consist would make someone feel at ease  
But overall very good !

title: Accessible
body: Rang first thing this morning, quickly got called back by GP and then seen in person within 2 hours. Receptionist were friendly and polite over the phone

title: Very inefficient
body: Been a patient of this surgery for three years and find them inefficient and rude, they seem not to be interested if your not wheeling a pram and have lost of children. There inadequate service, most of the staff have no understanding of what’s happening with there patients and don’t care. I find that frightening. Uncaring.

author: Enganche
title: Clearer guidance on process of calling 111
body:
My teenage daughter recently fractured her fibula and I just wanted to thank NHS 111 for facilitating a speedy assessment with a clinician listening in to the call and subsequent referral to University Hospital Crosshouse.  
Hospital website directed me to call the service direct to begin with and I was passed around the houses a bit and required a second call to the hospital before it was explained to me I needed to start the process via NHS 111. Clearer guidance on this would be helpful.  
However, once I started the process with NHS 111, everything then went much more smoothly. Total time from placing my initial call to NHS 111 to physically attending a referral appointment at Minor Injuries service was under 3 hours on a midweek afternoon. On arrival at ED, we were immediately taken to the ward and assigned a side room for assessment. Staff numbers at the service were greatly reduced from normal due to COVID-19 self isolation, but despite that we were seen in under 90 mins. Minimal time for wait to be taken to x-ray dept which was also done quickly.Minor Injuries staff were first class with my daughter and I throughout, despite the obvious strains on the service due to reduced staffing levels. Total time in hospital was just over 3 hours, including assisting my daughter with crutches as she’s never used them before and scheduling a follow up x-ray appointment.Thank you to everyone involved and keep up the good work!

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

title: Concerned for the staff
body: They have great staff at this practice, however I was very concerned that the nurse I spoke to today (30/09/2021) was barely about to complete the appointment without coughing to the point she had to mute the call and take a moment. You could tell in how she was breathing that she was having difficulty speaking to me. She assured me she was working from home, BUT you would think that the care of those caring for us would be of utmost importance, especially during this time. I really don't understand why staff would be expected to work when so clearly ill. I wish her a speedy recovery. Like I say, great staff, but maybe treat them with as much care as they treat us.

title: Outstanding care
body: I spent 9 nights at RPH. The care could not have been better. All the staff I came into contact with were brilliant, from consultants through to the cleaning and catering staff. Everyone was friendly and efficient whilst at the same time they were professional and caring. The nurses/HCAs on Ward 10 were particularly amazing; nothing I asked them to do/fetch for me was too much trouble. Sometimes they even brought things before I had the chance to ask for them. They never once made me feel as I was being a nuisance, even though they were obviously very busy. The food was very good. There was a sufficient variety, including light snacks, vegetarian options etc. The portions were of a good size and the quality of the food was also good. Sometimes the food was not very hot but I understand the logistical difficulties of getting the food to so many patients whilst it is still piping hot. This is an observation however, not a criticism. The standard of cleanliness was excellent. Beds were changed regularly and there was an opportunity to take a shower whenever you wanted. I was only supposed to stay for one night so I did not bring the necessary changes of clothes, toiletries etc. but shower gel, shampoo, towels etc. were all provided. I am due to have another operation this month and I sincerely hope that I am put on Ward 10 again. Thanks again to everyone for making my stay as pleasant as possible under the circumstances.

readBy.name: Lancashire Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Can never contact by phone
body: Both my wife and I have ongoing medical conditions, yet whilst trying to contact Pathfields Medical group we have spent literally hours on the phone trying to contact yet telephones are never answered. No wonder they are not listed within the top 10 Plymouth surgeries. Absolute atrocious patient care. As if people are not stressed enough with the things going on in everyday live. This alone is enough to stress people out and raise ones blood pressure.

title: Terrible practice
body: They are understaffed and need more doctors, this was told to me via the staff working there. Impossible to get an appointment, terrible queue lengths when you phone. They admitted they have far too many patients, and more will arrive due to the new houses being built, about time Taurus invested money in the surgery

title: Good telephone experience
body: The team were very good in answering phone today (in under 45 minutes and/or up to 40 calls).  The staff were (reception team) very informative, knowledgeable and took time to be understanding and thorough with their responses and action to be taken.  Hopefully this will continue after such a year long experience of bad service from the practice

title: Rude, unhelpful reception/admin staff
body: Poor customer service, blunt and came across as very rude over the telephone. Unhelpful and would do the bare minimum. The impression I got was they did not care, expressed how urgent the matter was and still nothing.

title: Excellent service
body:
I was referred to the emergency eye unit by my GP who arranged a 9.30 appointment on 29.9.21
The department was easy to find and I was seen after a very short wait by Ch....who carried out various tests and after speaking to a doctor told me I needed to go to phlebotomy for a blood test. I walk with two sticks and she was able to give me directions. On the way I met a helpful guy in turquoise fleece who took me the shortest route. Explained that the results were urgent and that I would be waiting in the eye unit. Very kind phlebotomists and back to the unit via the coffee shop. While I was waiting the lovely Ch... would check I was and apologised for delay. Then I had a scan, another wait and seen by excellent, efficient and empathetic Doctor D. She managed to rule out the condition the GP was concerned about and was very reassuring. Also advised me on my eye care and will have a follow up appointment in 6 weeks. All in all a very good experience.

title: Awful practice
body: The reception staff have no idea what they're doing. It's almost impossible to get an appointment including for a child under 18 months. Recently I had to make an emergency appointment for my child which I managed to get however I turned up and was told the appointment was cancelled due to the doctor not wanting to work late and they decided to go home. I then had to go to A&E at 6pm with my young child also whilst I am in my third trimester of pregnancy. They have also recently refused to sign a fit to fly letter for me even though my pregnancy is uncomplicated and I am within the acceptable week range. I've never experienced a doctors surgery like this before - just awful. I am in the process of changing surgeries.

title: Excellent
body: SpaMedica - in my opinion are a fantastic fascility on the Wirral . I’m an retired theatre sister so I knew what to expect . They went beyond my expectations caring, professional from the reception nursing and surgeon . I can’t express how wonderful they are . I can’t wait to have my second eye done . Please pass on my thanks to this exceptional team .

author: cafehr48
title: staff very patient
body:
Bad things - noisy at night with radio playing too long. Staff chatty too loudly at times as well (now I know a lot about them). Everyone was very good and caring.  
Staff very patient:  
Answered questions as much as possible but still have a few unanswered. Very helpful and cautious if I walked or moved. Everything kept in order and clean.

author: dracoqc68
title: They care for the babies as if they were their own
body:
My son spent 43 days in the neonatal unit in Craigavon. The care he received from when he was admitted to intensive care right up until our departure recently was nothing short of amazing.  
The nurses in the unit care for the babies as if they were their own. Not only do they care for the babies but they look after the parents too in what is such a difficult time.  
The special touches they do for the parents for example, boards with a story on them written by the babies every day to making cards from the babies for the parents to take home. Things like that that are way above and beyond their job description. Brilliant staff who genuinely care.  
Thanks so much to all the staff working there! You are a credit to the NHS.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: 51 year old woman
title: Expertise, compassion and humanity
body:
I had been experiencing severe pelvic pain and swelling. I was known to this gynaecology Department through outpatient appointments with the lovely Dr. Morales, who had been investigating my symptoms. Dr Morales had advised me that I was to attend the hospital if my symptoms worsened, which they did so I attended accident and emergency on Friday in the late afternoon.  
I was seen by a nice registrar who examined me and referred me to gynaecologist Dr. Reilly who advised me that emergency hysterectomy surgery was required and that she would carry out the surgery that evening. I was so grateful that she was willing to treat my pain, there and then, despite any plans she may have had for her Friday evening....sorry and thanks Dr. Reilly.  
I was then taken to a bedroom in ward 6 FVRI by a lovely student nurse called Sophie and prepped for surgery. I was very comforted to have my own bedroom with ensuite shower room as I experience high levels of anxiety related to privacy and comfort (a bit of a brat maybe but it really did impact my wellbeing both then and post surgery).  
I can not remember the name of the lovely anaesthetist who visited me but do remember feeling very safe in his care and reassured by his manner and expertise. The two anaesthetic nurses who took me to surgery and looked after me were a highlight of this strange experience....they were so funny and kind. I apologise for any and all of my bizarre ramblings as I came out of the anaesthetic.....I remember being keen to hold my baby!!!  
My next memory is of Friday night or Saturday morning, being back in my room in ward 6 and being very gently and kindly cared for by the two night nurses (who I thought were actual angels in my post anaesthetic state). I was still wanting to hold my baby and they were SO gentle in their explanations about there being no baby!  
I am now home recovering from my surgery and feeling much better than I did before surgery. I am a bit uncomfortable having undergone this surgery but NOTHING compared to the pre operative pain. Relief does not come close to describing how it feels to be recovering rather than living in pain.  
Throughout this experience, I was treated with dignity and respect and felt that I was treated as a whole human rather than a collection of symptoms. I can not begin to thank the workers who operated on and cared for me during my hospital stay. The nurses in ward 6 were professional, knowledgeable and compassionate and a great comfort to me during my stay (especially wee Heidi who called herself an auxiliary but actually is a Superstar). The housekeeping staff were kind, efficient and entertaining....making my days much less dull.  
Overall, this was as positive an experience as humanly possible and I would like to commend Dr. Reilly and the team most highly for their expertise, compassion and humanity. 😍

author: EllieP
title: Covid vaccination centre
body:
I am a healthcare worker and recently received an invitation to make an appointment for my covid booster. I checked that 6 months had passed since my last vaccination and booked an appointment online (and it was a very positive, straightforward process). However, at the entrance I was met a nurse chatting to two security guards from the shopping centre where the vaccination centre was based. In front of the two security guards, they asked me which dose I was attending for. When I replied it was my third, they wouldn't let me in unless I told them the dates of my other two vaccines. I said I couldn't recall without looking it up, but I had an appointment. I was told this wasn't good enough as some people with appointments were attending within the wrong time frame and they insisted I told her when my last vaccine was before they would let me in. I said I'd have to look it up so instead showed them my appointment confirmation. They came across as rude and sarcastic and told me it didn't matter that I had an appointment, as it still might be within the wrong timeframe. I genuinely wasn't sure if they were going to let me in, despite having booked an appointment in advance. They eventually relented and said the team inside would need check. Once inside, I had no issues at all. The nurse administering the vaccine was able to bring up my notes and check that I had correctly booked an appointment, prior to administering me my vaccine.  
As a clinician who has worked in the health service for 11 years and also completed public health training and a dissertation on vaccine hesitancy, I am incredibly concerned by the difficulty I had even entering the vaccination centre. Surely we are wanting to encourage people to attend for their vaccine and then also return for follow up doses? The nurse actually reduced me to tears by the time I made it inside to check-in with the admin staff (who were absolutely wonderful). As someone attending, with an appointment, I don't understand why it was so difficult for me to get through the front entrance? Also, as someone who has also worked in administering the vaccine, I am fully aware that the actual vaccinator is the one responsible for checking dates so I don't understand why I was questioned about this before even in the door? Lastly, I am appalled to have been asked confidential questions in a shopping centre, in front of two strangers, as well as feeling accused of making my appointment inappropriately - it was quite humiliating. If it was necessary to ask me confidential questions prior to letting me inside, then this should have been done somewhere privately. To question me like this in front of two other people and reduce me to tears when I was simple attending a pre-booked appointment is not acceptable. I would never expect to hold a consultation with my patients in the waiting room or a corridor, and I would not expect to try and turn someone away who has a valid appointment.  
Aside from this, I do want to highlight that the rest of the experience was excellent. From the compassionate receptionist, to the staff nurse and HCA who checked my notes and administered my vaccinations (I got my flu vaccine too which was a pleasant surprise!). We chatted about gardening - if it is possible to feedback to them directly then please let them know that after the encounter I had on the way in, I appreciated their kindness and friendliness and their professionalism. The team manning the seating areas were equally as professional.  
Overall, the experience could have been very positive. I do however worry that I am not the only one who encountered this difficulty on the door. I would be grateful if this could be fed-back as I really don't think this was an appropriate way to be treated - although I found it upsetting on a personal level, I am mostly concerned about the impact that treating people like this might have on vaccine uptake.

author: nmc25
title: A&E/Ward 19
body:
Thank you to all the staff on shift in late September.  
A&E was very busy but with clear expected wait times shown and seen well within them. Can’t really remember anyone’s names but nurse ?Mark explained all tests for our little boy and made sure a nervous mum was attended to aswell! The drs saw us promptly and made a plan, liasing with ward 19.  
The girls in the ward were again very kind and welcoming....providing lots of wipes when the vomiting started! You made the experience less daunting and we are on the road to recovery - thanks again x

author: Heelpain
title: Great Podiatry Dept in Banbridge
body: Have had plantar fascitiis since Feb 2019 and was seen by Podiatry in Banbridge for orthotics and have felt a difference !  Been referred to ICATS but at least experiencing less pain.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Teef
title: Made me feel I was useless
body:
I went to an appointment today.  
The person dealing with me was not very pleasant. They told me if I didn’t smoke I would not need to be there. That I shouldn’t be there till I’m 80.  
They then told me to not talk. They did not explain anything to me, put me on a treadmill for about a minute, told me they think it’s my back and not my legs. I’m in a mobility scooter from the start of the year because of pain in my legs. I can’t walk far. Then they told me to go back to my doctor.  
I waited about 2 years for this appointment and I left in tears. They made me feel like I was useless.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: Superlanc
title: Amazing team
body: The staff were amazing from the Ultrasound lady to the Gynaecology team on Ward 1B. It was fantastic to have an all woman team who understood how scary this can be. They showed compassion, kindness, good humour and a dedication to their jobs. Pilgrim Hospital should be very proud of their team.

author: zebraqe37
title: Patient Care
body: My 82 year old father was referred to Chaucer Ward at Northwick Park Hospital yesterday by his GP for a swollen finger.  Extremely pleased with the way my father was treated, not only by the staff on the ward but also by Dr Raj who took time out explain the situation and made sure my dad was well cared for.  Thank you #NHSstaff

readBy.name: London North West University Healthcare NHS Trust

author: TomD21
title: I was uncertain to begin with
body: I have been attending Psychological therapy at Oldbridge House, WHSCT over the past year. I was abit uncertain to begin with as to whether it would help with my anxiety and depression or not. I have learnt tools to use at trigger points and although it all seems straight forward this course breaks it down and gives you a better understanding. It helps you cope when you are having down days. Bronagh has been patient and understanding and is easy to chat too about difficult subjects. It is left with me now to put into practice.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: zuluwd56
title: Staff needed for patients waiting to be seen in A&E reception area
body:
I have been in hospital for almost 2 weeks. I had to wait in A&E for 12 hours before being seen. The chairs in A&E reception area are uncomfortable. I was not offered food during this 12 hours and because I came by ambulance I forgot to bring my purse so could not purchase from shop. When I was admitted to yellow bay the HCA offered me Tea and Toast and ensured I was comfortable. The bleeping in the bay gave me a headache but this cannot be avoided. If I could improve anything in A&E it would be a staff member to look after patients waiting in reception area and to somehow make the machines bleep less.  
I was moved to 3 south and the staff are friendly and look after me well. It is a busy ward but I have no complaints. The meals are very good, I enjoy them a bit too much.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust
